5177618/5173619/5198616.title: Racing at Weddings
5177618/5173619/5198616.text:
I Know you would like to hear all about  racing at Weddings. All the neighbours and friends would be invited. They would all come on the day appointed with their horse and sadles and their horses and rider - carts to the girls home. The man of the house would have a few gallons of whiskey and a barrel of porter ready. When they were all assembled a big dinner was prepared for them and lots of liquor. Then they danced for a few hours and after that, they went to the church to be married. There would be some on horse-back and some in side-cars. When the married couple were leaving the church rice would be sprinkled on them. Then they would sit into their carts and gallop to the brides home and dance until the cock crows in the morning.



I know you would like to hear about dancing at cross roads. Long ago a dance was held at every cross road on Sunday after the dinner and in the evenings. A large crowd of boys and girls would attend and dance for hours. Step-dancing, reel-sets and a number of old men had hornpipes. Long ago a man used to be going around to the farmers houses teaching step-dance and a number of the neighbours used attend. He used stay a week at each house. There were no concertines or fiddles that time at the dances only jigging, flute playing and whistling. They used to stay dancing and singing until late in the evening.

5177620/5173681/5198885.title: Béaloideas
5177620/5173681/5198885.text: "Shrove time is coming the dear happy time, of pancakes and puddings and whiskey and wines, I put on my bonnet and blue satin gown, for I'm going to be married to my Buachaillín Donn".               ------------------In the year 1860 an Aunt of the teachers got married to a man named Mr. Moloney in Post Office Feakle her own house. All the neighbours and friends were invited to the wedding and each of them brought a turkey or a goose. There was great feasting in the house with lots of punch and whiskey go leor. All the old men and women at that time brought their voilens and flutes to the wedding, and some sang Irish Comalies and danced," and if they dont live happy that we may.

5177626/5173971/5200258.title: Piseogs
5177626/5173971/5200258.text:
A woman to make a match is considered a very unlucky thing.A woman (mother) never goes to the son's wedding nor the daughter's wedding.The father if alive gives his daughter away - if not the eldest brother does so.When the girl marries and goes to her new home, she never enters her father's home for a month.The belief is she would have no children if she did.the bride must wear something new.  Something blue and something borrowed.When on their way to the church a near friend passed the bride out and when she returned from the church the first to meet her should be a man (not a woman).Old irons were placed in car when she was leaving the church to go in her husband's car on her way to her new home.An old shoe was thrown after them when leaving the church or rice and now I have seen in our church confetti (bought at Woolworths)At the present time they have motors no matter how short the distance.In my young days they walked if any way near to church or they came in side cars.I often saw thirty cars together at the church and I saw four different marriages one evening.

Timber Bicycle.   John Leary. Knockback. Banter made a timer bicycle. He used ride it from Knockback to Banteer mass and one day Canon Morrisey,late P.P of Banter mounted the bicycle and rode it through the village.Clock - John Leary also made a clock which was worked by a stream of water.Sugáin Chairs. James Cronin Gurraue,Banteer used make chair with twisted rushes and sally twigs.



A travelling man arranged a marriage between a girl from Kilcorney named Kate Walsh and a boy from Macroom .Both parties were unacquanited. The man in Macroom wanted a wife and the girl in kilcorney wanted a husband.The old man in his travels through the county arranged correspondence between the parties. Steal a personal interview was brought about and the  man made a visit to the girls house. Money matters were settled and the marriage took place. The parties were  married in Banteer by the present P.P. canon Brew.

5264182/5263677/5264234.title: A Foolish Husband
5264182/5263677/5264234.text: Grandmother told me a story, which is really true, about a man who was getting married. After the ceremony, the priest told him to catch his wife by the arm and bring her down the chapel. The man asked the priest which would he grip. This man was 70 years and his wife 25. The priest looked at him and said "you are old enough now to have sense. Catch your wife of course." The man was very stupid and when he was coming out he didn't know whether it was the bride or bridesmaid he married.
